data.text: Contents
Introduction

This policy sets out the formal recognition of trade unions, time off for trade union duties and the partnership arrangements between Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSEFT) and the Trade Unions who represent staff.

The Trust acknowledges the role that trade union representation plays in facilitating good employee relations across the Trust, which in turn plays an important role in the effective delivery of health services.

The Trust also recognises the importance of providing Trade Union representatives with the necessary support to be able to carry out their duties and activities efficiently. These involve the provision of appropriate facilities and time-off to perform trade union duties.
The spirit of this agreement is one of co-operation between parties – the Trust, its managers, the trade unions, local staff representatives and staff.
Purpose

The policy is based on establishing a clear framework for the recognition of Trade Unions, requesting time-off for trade union duties and fostering a culture of consultation, negotiation and involvement of Trade Unions in decision-making
The agreement is between Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (hereinafter called the "Trust") and the following unions now recognised in this agreement:
British and Irish Orthoptic Society
British Association of Occupational Therapists
British Dental Association
British Dietetic Association
British Medical Association
College of Podiatry
Royal College of Midwives
Royal College of Nursing
Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists
Society of Radiographers
The Chartered Society of Physiotherapy
Unite the Union
Unison
Management in Partnership (MIP)
Scope

This agreement gives guidance to the Trust and Trade Unions on the implementation of The Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 (Amendment Order) 2013 (TULRA) and reflects the advice given in the Code issued by the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (‘ACAS').

TULRA gives certain trade union officials a right to reasonable paid time off work to discharge certain functions or to undergo training (s168); and for an employee who is a member of a union to claim unpaid time off work to participate in certain activities (s170). This Agreement also covers Trade Unions recognition, time-off for trade union duties and partnership working arrangements with the Trust.

The Employment Rights (Dispute Resolution) Act 1998 made minor amendments to previous legislation and the statutory provisions are supplemented by an ACAS Code of Practice (‘The Code'). The Code gives practical guidance to employers and unions on arranging for time off.

There is also a statutory right to time off work for non-union employee representatives in respect of consultation on transfers of undertakings and collective redundancies (TULRA s188(1) and TUPE Reg 10(2)). Such responsibilities are only to be elected where there is no recognised trade union and this agreement does not therefore deal with their position.

The parties to this agreement confirm this is a relevant agreement within the meaning of partnership working. The scope of such negotiation shall be those areas defined in Section 178 (2) of the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 (TULRA) and any other areas agreed by both parties.
Definitions

table_items.text: A staff organisation and/or a professional association recognised by the Trust and any such organisation which may in future be so recognised

An employee who has been elected or appointed in accordance with the rules of the trade union to be a representative of all or some of the union's members in a particular workplace or area of work administered by the Trust (including an employee who has been elected or appointed Chairman or Secretary of a trade union branch) and who, in accordance with the provisions of Section 7 of this agreement, is recognised by the Trust as an accredited representative of the trade union

Means the remuneration the employee would have received if they ordinarily had worked during the period when the time off was taken or, if the employee's remuneration varies with the amount of work done, an amount calculated by reference to their average hourly earnings
Should be read and interpreted with regard to the level of activity and position of the respective trade union representative.

Is different from collective bargaining or consultation and is at the heart of shared decision making with the outcomes of processes agreed and supported by both parties. This involves engagement from conception to delivery.

Keeping all parties fully informed of relevant matters at the earliest opportunity. This will include sharing and discussing information regarding the Trust's planning and workforce intentions, financial position and other relevant issues appertaining to the Trust in a transparent and timely manner.

Involves a transparent approach, taking account of employee views through nationally agreed frameworks via accredited trade union representatives throughout the process and every opportunity is given to provide feedback irrespective of the circumstances. In proposals and decisions, such as organisational change and non-contractual employment policies and procedures, the systematic and routine involvement of staff and Trade Unions through both formal consultation and informal engagement will be integral at all times.
Will mean a commitment in good faith to jointly reach agreement and resolve issues between all parties.

Is the official process by which Trade Unions negotiate with employers on behalf of staff including their members with respect to their terms and conditions of employment and customary practice. This process of negotiation, in good faith, between the employer and recognised Trade Union representatives and organisations with a view to reaching an agreement leads to the determination of terms and conditions of employment.
Refers to those Trade Union recognised by MSEFT for the purpose of negotiation on pay and working conditions on behalf of the Trust workforce and for the purposes of partnership working

Refers to activities as set out in Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992. But does not does not extent to activities which themselves consist of industrial action, whether or not in contemplation or furtherance of a trade dispute. Or any activity that may create a conflict with the employer

data.text: General principles
The Trust and the Trade Unions recognise they have in common the following objectives:
The effective operation and development of the Trust
The development and success of the Trust through striving for excellence in patient care, managing our resources effectively and improving staff working lives.
The maintenance of good employee relations across the Trust
To ensure employment practices in the Trust are conducted to the highest possible standards
To enhance effective communication with staff throughout the Trust
To achieve greater participation and involvement of staff in the running and development of the Trust
To ensure the treatment of staff is fair and equitable in dispute matters
To work in partnership to achieve the best results in pursuing its aims and objectives.
The Trust and the Trade Unions recognise the diversity of the workforce is a key priority and diverse needs will be met by treating each other with respect, courtesy, and dignity.

All parties will work in partnership to embed and deliver the spirit of the statutory provisions set out in the Equality Act 2010. This will include employment practices with a joint commitment to eliminate discrimination and associated behaviours detailed in the legislation.

A commitment is made by all parties within this agreement to embed positive diversity actions that will deliver best practice within The Trust and support a culture defining the organisation as an ‘employer of choice' for the communities it serves.

The Trust believes representative Trade Unions lead to good employee relations and the Trust supports the principle / rights of staff to join a trade union, although membership is not a condition of employment.
Benefits of working in partnership
Key benefits of working in partnership include:
Improved morale with staff feeling valued and engaged
Service delivery improvements and patient care.
Delivering positive change in the workplace
Faster and more effective decision-making.
Establishing the Trust as an employer of choice.
Resolving local issues effectively
Measurable positive change through joint working on national benchmarking exercises including the annual NHS staff survey
Behaviours that support partnership working
Partnership working requires adopting and embedding Trust values and behaviours from the parties involved.
Dealing with problems informally at the lowest appropriate level is an important principle
The Trust will:
Deliver and maintain effective and timely communication
Adopt a culture where managers involve staff in decision- making
Enable and empower managers and staff to develop effective partnership working
Trade Unions will:
Work in partnership to develop and deploy employment policies
Keep the Trust informed of changes to accredited representatives
Managers will:
Adopt an inclusive style of management, engaging staff and accredited representatives on ways of working and addressing key issues
Keep staff informed on a regular basis
Recognise the importance of the role of elected staff representatives and support them, for example through time off in line with the time off agreement
Managers, Staff and Trade Union representatives will:
Deal with all problems at the lowest appropriate level in the organisation
Treat each other with dignity, respect and professionalism
Partnership committees
The Trust and the Trade Unions agree to set up a Joint Negotiation Committee (JNC) consisting of representatives from both the Trust and Trade Unions. The functions of the JNC shall include:
Information

The Trust undertakes to supply the Trade Unions with the necessary information to carry out effective consultation and negotiation. This includes the Trust's relevant Workforce information, employment policies, procedures, proposed amendments and additions. The Trust will additionally supply information on recent and probable developments of the Trust and its economic situation.
Consultation

To have proper consultation with staff to enable feedback and discussion before decisions are taken concerning matters directly affecting the interests of staff. The Trust will additionally consult on the current situation, structure and development of employment across the Trust, especially any change to employment and on changes in work or contractual relations, including redundancies and transfers.
Negotiation

To negotiate and reach agreement on issues not covered by the national Terms and Conditions of employment. This may include pay related issues and a range of employment matters including redundancy pathways and redeployment, TUPE, reorganisation of staff and relocation of offices. This will also include any other items, which both sides agree to be discussed.
Joint Negotiating Committee (JNC)

The Joint Negotiating Committee will be the main mechanism for negotiation on workforce matters. The parties agree to work in partnership through the JNC to reach reasonable solutions to all relevant matters.
Membership / terms of reference

The Trade Union membership at the JNC will be based on one trade union representative from each of the recognised Trade Unions. The membership will also include the staffside chair who will have voting rights and two deputy StaffSide chairs who will be non-voting members.
Management representatives
The following representatives will form the membership from the Trust:
Chief Executive (twice a year)
Managing Directors
Chief People and Organisational Development Director
Deputy Chief Executive
Director of Workforce
Director of Organisational Development
Director of Human Resources Operations
Chief Nurse Officer or Deputy
Chief Estates and Facilities Officer or Deputy
Chief Finance Officer or Deputy
Group Head of Employee Relations
Associate Directors of Human Resources
Medical Directors (on a rotational basis)
Meetings

The Chief People and Organisational Development Director and Staffside Chair will chair the meetings on a rotational basis and the agenda for the meetings will be agreed between the membership and the Chairs. The Chair(s) will ensure JNC meetings are conducted in an appropriate manner and that the agreed agenda is followed.
The Joint Negotiating Committee will meet every two months. Any cancellation or postponement of JNC meetings will be with the Chair(s) approval with as much notice as possible.

The meetings will be scheduled for two hours with a timed agenda. All agenda papers in addition to the previous meeting minutes, action notes and the meeting agenda will be circulated seven days in advance of any formal meeting unless in exceptional circumstances.

A Staffside pre-meet will take place between the trade unions and any invited regional representatives for one hour before JNC to enable trade unions to establish where possible a joint position on key agenda items
Points of Procedure

Regional reps may be invited to attend JNC meetings on an adhoc basis only with both Chair(s) approval. In order to speak at the full meeting, they must have attended the Staff Side pre-meeting. One staffside representative may attend from any union as an observer with prior permission from the chairs for their personal development and learning activity, but will not be able to contribute to the meeting or vote on decisions.
Other individuals may be invited to attend JNC to deputise for standing members or where their presence and expertise will add value to specific meetings.
There may be extraordinary circumstances when a meeting needs to be arranged outside of the normal meeting calendar and at short notice. Attendees will be informed as promptly as possible.
Quorum
The JNC shall be deemed quorate when there are six members of the Trust and six trade union representatives present. Decisions will be confirmed by a majority vote.
Sub groups

The JNC may establish relevant Task and Finish Groups to work on relevant projects or work streams. Subgroups will also be established to pursue the work of the committee. The Terms of Reference for the groups and role descriptions will be agreed in consultation with the Trust. The Sub Groups will include:
Policy sub group (PSG)

The Head of Employee Relations or deputy will chair this subgroup. This group will be responsible for policy development and consultation working with Trade Unions. The membership will include representation from the recognised Trade Unions. Also, one Human Resources Business Partner from each site, operational and clinical managers from each site and Employee Relations Manager(s). Policies will be submitted to JNC for approval and ratified by normal vote at JNC. This sub group will meet monthly.
Staffside group

A Staffside Group will be established comprising a forum on each of the three major sites. All trade unions representatives will form membership of the Staffside Group. The Staffside Group will agree a process to elect a Staffside Chair (also a site lead) and two site leads (Deputies) who will be entitled to attend JNC (see 9.2). Staffside site meetings will be chaired by the Site Lead (or a nominated deputy). The Staffside Chair will inform the Employee Relations Team on an annual basis of the election arrangements and the names and contact details of those elected. The elected site leads will have a mandate to represent Staffside on that site for any urgent site-based issues.
The Staffside forum on each of the sites will meet monthly for 1.5 hours to discuss local site issues and relevant employee relation matters and escalate to Local Partnership Forums.
Local Partnership Forums (LPF)
Local Partnership Forums (LPFs) will be established on each site. The Site Associate Director of Human Resources and the Staffside Site Lead will chair the forum on a rotational basis.

The forum will be scheduled by Site Associate Director of HR and will meet bimonthly for 2 hours to ensure local and site issues and relevant employee relations matters are discussed and escalated to JNC as appropriate. The forum membership will include Head of Employee Relations and any trade union representatives who wish to attend. Forums will also include invited site operational teams and relevant stakeholders.

The agenda will be agreed between the Chairs and members will be invited to submit agenda items. The previous meeting minutes, action notes and the next agenda should be circulated at least 7 calendar days before any formal meeting. Any cancellation or postponement of the forum will be with the Chair(s) approval with as much notice as possible
Joint Local Negotiating Committee (JLNC)

The Trust will also set up a Joint Local Negotiating Committee. The role of the JLNC, as per the JLNC Constitution, shall be to negotiate, consult, discuss and agree all matters affecting medical and dental staff in the Trust pertaining to terms and conditions of service, working arrangements, policies and procedures relevant to medical and dental staff in the Trust, including arrangements for the application of national terms and conditions of service. Please note that the above are only examples and not intended to be an exhaustive list.

The JLNC shall comprise of representatives of all grades of Medical and Dental Staff from across all sites of the Trust and shall include the BMA Full Time Officer. The Medical and Dental members of the LNC shall be members of the BMA/BDA and be accredited in line with BMA policy.
Terms of reference

The JLNC is invited and shall provide a representative to attend the Trust's overarching trade union forum (JNC) and this representative will provide an update to the JLNC on all relevant wider staff matters. The terms of reference for the JLNC and any other arrangements are as detailed in the constitution set out in Appendix
Accreditation of staff representatives

A recognised trade union will confirm with the Trust the names and contact details of its representatives in each work place or area of work administered by the Trust having regard to the national rules of the organisation and the number and location of work groups for which each representative will be responsible.

Trade unions shall notify the Trust promptly in writing (or on request) when staff representatives are appointed, resign or when other changes in representation are made. Such notifications should be made to the Chief People and Organisational Development Director and copied to the Head of Employee Relations. The Employee Relations team will maintain a record of trade union representatives across the Trust.
Full Time officers of trade union organisations

Full Time employed Officers of recognised staff organisations may visit premises administered by the Trust and hold or attend meetings with their members. In line with good practice and wherever possible, they should notify the relevant Staffside Site lead / Branch Secretary and Head of Employee Relations in writing, in advance of any visit and observe site protocols.
Time off for trade union duties

The Trust will permit accredited staff representatives reasonable time off work with pay to enable them to perform trade union duties concerned with industrial relations between the Trust and its employees, This will be subject to service operational requirements and compliance with the conditions contained in this agreement.
Reasonable time off work with pay will be granted to accredited staff representatives for the following purposes:
Consultation /negotiation with the Trust and Trade Union
To attend meetings called for informing members of the outcome of Trust negotiations or consultations
To meet with other staff representatives or with full time trade union representatives
To investigate issues raised and liaise with Trust colleagues as required
To meet with members to prepare for casework meetings
To appear on behalf of a member or members at a formal meeting where the attendance of the representative is requested by the member or member(s)

To appear on behalf of a member or members before an outside official body, such as an Employment Tribunal or Medical Appeals Tribunal, which is dealing with an industrial relations matter directly concerning the Trust and where the attendance of the representative is required in connection with the presentation of the case
To attend meetings called by the Trust where the presence of the representative is requested by the management representative convening the meeting
To attend monthly Staffside or Local Partnership Forum meetings.
To attend staff induction days or formal meetings

Subject to operational requirements of the Service, the Trust will permit the granting of time off work with pay to trade union elected officials and accredited representatives of staff organisations to enable them to take part, each as a representative of a branch or branches, or a section of members, in meetings of official bodies of the organisation
Union learning representatives

The Trust shall permit an employee who is a member of an independent trade union recognised by the employer and a learning representative of the trade union, to take paid time off during their working hours for any of the following purposes/activities in relation to qualifying members of the trade union:
Analysing, learning or training needs
Providing information and advice about learning or training matters, or
Arranging learning or training or
Promoting the value of learning or training
Health and safety

The Safety Representatives and Safety Committees Regulations of 1977 regulation 4(2)(a) requires that employers allow union health and safety representatives paid time off, as is necessary, during working hours, to perform their functions. These functions will include:
investigating potential hazards and dangerous occurrences
investigating complaints by members
investigating the causes of accidents
inspecting documents relevant to safety in the workplace
making representations to the employer
representing members' interests in meetings with enforcement inspectors
receiving information from the employer
receiving information from enforcement inspectors
being consulted by the employer about issues relating to health and safety in the workplace
attending safety committee meetings
Line managers shall grant reasonable time off with pay to perform the duties set out above or Trade unions may discuss any special requests with the Trust.
Conditions relating to the granting of time off work to trade unions for trade union duties

Managers are authorised to grant reasonable time off work with pay to accredited staff representatives and in the event of any branch interpretative difficulty in this regard should seek the advice from the Head of Employee Relations. Representatives with national or regional seats can request additional facility to attend national or regional meetings /events.

An accredited representative requiring time off work shall seek permission, through their immediate Manager, as far in advance as is practicable and shall indicate the general nature of the trade union duty for which time off work is required, the expected period of absence and where they can be contacted in a personal emergency

Managers in considering requests from accredited representatives for time off work must not unreasonably withhold but may take account of the overriding operational requirements of the service. It is therefore necessary for a Manager who refuses such a request to be able to demonstrate sound reasons for the refusal and must provide upon request to Head of Employee Relations within 5 days a written confirmation for the reasons for any refusal and review that decision on request.

An accredited representative who has been granted time off work for Trade Union duties should not leave their place of work without informing their manager and should not for the purpose of the undertaking of those duties, enter a department without first introducing themselves and explaining the reason for their visit. On returning to duty, the representative should inform their manager.

Managers who are accredited representatives should obtain consent from a more Senior Manager to approve the granting of time off work for Trade Union activities to other accredited representatives of their own staff organisation or themselves.
Time off work for the training of trade union officials

The Trust will, subject to operational requirements, grant reasonable time off work with pay to ensure accredited staff representatives are trained and briefed on National Agreements and Industrial Relations through attendance at relevant training courses. This will not include payment of fees and expenses.

A request for an accredited representative to be granted time off work for attending a training course specified above, should be made to the line manager of the accredited representative in writing at least one month prior to the date of the training. Where the request is refused, the line manager should provide a written response within seven calendar days to the Trade Union and Head of Employee Relations; otherwise, the representative will assume that approval has been granted.

The attendance of accredited representatives as staff of the Trust at other training courses of an industrial relations nature, which may be organised by or on behalf of the National Health Service or by an outside body, shall be at the discretion of the Trust. In those cases where attendance is approved the Trust will grant leave of absence with pay.
Time spent by accredited representatives on duties concerned with industrial relations matters outside their normal working hours

The Trust recognises accredited representatives may face problems of representation arising from the differing hours or shifts worked by them and their members and from the fact that their own working hours may not coincide with the working hours of management.

To assist accredited representatives in overcoming this, the Trust may grant, at the discretion of the appropriate manager who will take account of the operational requirements of the service, time-in lieu for the following purposes:
To attend meetings of an industrial relations nature initiated by management, where the attendance of the representative is requested by the management representative convening the meeting.

To attend interviews with and on behalf of a member or members on grievance and disciplinary matters concerning a member or members and the Trust, where the presence of the representative is requested by the member or members.
To appear on behalf of a member or members before a Trust Appeals Committee or Committee of Inquiry, where the attendance of the representative is requested by the member.

To appear on behalf of a member or members before an outside official body, such as an Employment Tribunal or Medical Appeals Tribunal, which is dealing with an industrial relations matter directly concerning the Trust and where the attendance of the representative is required in connection with the presentation of the case
To attend meetings called specifically to inform members of the outcome of negotiations or consultations with the Trust.

A request for time off in lieu should be made by an accredited union representative to their manager, as far in advance as is practicable, specifying the nature and anticipated duration of the duty. As soon as possible following the completion of the duty, the accredited representative should inform their manager of the time spent on the duty exclusive of travelling time.
Paid time off work for members (including accredited representatives) of recognised staff organisations to participate in trade union duties
The Trust recognises to operate effectively, staff organisations will require the active participation of members and accredited representatives
The Trust will permit, subject to operational requirements, reasonable time off with pay to members and accredited representatives for the following purposes:
To attend Agenda for Change meetings as a member of the Staff Side

To enable two members from each site of a branch of a recognised staff organisation to attend Conferences, subject to a maximum of six members of any one Trade Union from the Trust and to the time off work required by a member for the purpose not exceeding one working week. Members who hold a national Trade Union position are not included in the above number
To attend the workplace AGM or other annual meetings as may be arranged, for the purpose of electing branch officers and committee members
To attend meetings convened, to inform members of the outcome of negotiations or consultations with the Trust
To attend annual general meetings and other national conferences relevant to the individual union, numbers to be agreed with the Employee Relations team.

Requests for the time off work with pay under the provisions of this section shall be made by the employee or if a large proportion of staff are involved by the employees' accredited representative(s), to the appropriate manager as far in advance as possible, indicating the purpose for which time off is required and the expected period of absence.

Managers are authorised to grant time off work with pay (having regard to an operational requirements and may arrange with other staff to cover the work of staff taking time off) with the exception that requests to attend Annual Conferences must also be reported to Employee Relations team.

Where, within the provisions of this policy a trade union organisation or accredited representative considers it necessary to hold meetings of members during working hours, the staff organisation or accredited representative shall seek to agree the arrangements with management as far in advance as is practicable.
Where meetings necessarily involve a large proportion of staff at the workplace at any one time, management and the staff organisation or accredited representative shall agree:
(a) A convenient time which minimises the effect on the Service (for example, towards the end of a shift or working day or just before or after a meal break) And
(b) To leave at work such members as are essential for safety or operational purposes
The Trust will fund provide specific time-off for the following roles:
Unpaid Time off Work for members (including accredited representatives) of recognised staff organisations to participate in Trade Union Activities

Request for staff to be granted time off work without pay under the provisions of this Section shall be made by a fulltime officer or branch secretary of the staff organisation, in writing to the appropriate Manager, as far in advance as is practicable. The request should specify the purpose for the time off work and the period of the proposed absence. Any disputes should be referred to the Head of Employee Relations.
Special conditions relating to industrial action

The provisions contained in this agreement relating to time off work for trade union duties and activities and facilities for staff organisations are subject to recognition there is no obligation on the Trust to consider requests from accredited representatives and members for time off work for trade union activities, which relate to any industrial action.

Furthermore, the Trust reserves the right to withdraw from a staff organisation, or from any of its members who are taking industrial action against the Trust, some or all of the provisions contained in this agreement, with the exception that:
Where an accredited representative is not taking part in industrial action but represents members who are so involved, the provisions shall not be withdrawn from them
Where a group of members not taking part in industrial action is directly

affected by the industrial action of other employees, such group of members and their accredited representative(s) may, subject to the approval of management, be permitted reasonable time off work to attend an emergency meeting, provided this is not called for the purpose of considering an extension of the industrial action.
Recording of trade unions activity

The Trust is required to record and publish information on how much time is spent by their trade union officers on paid trade union facility time. This information must be broken down into the total number of hours spent by trade union officials on facility time, and from that figure how much is spent on trade union duties and activities.

Trade union officials are therefore required to complete the form attached at appendix [2] to this policy setting out these details. The form must be completed and returned to Head of Employee Relations annually (March st).
Facilities for accredited representatives of staff organisations
Accredited trade unions will be afforded all reasonable facilities to enable them to carry out their duties effectively. These could include:
Use of notice boards on Trust premises
Designated office accommodation with telephone
Access to rooms or offices within the Trust for meetings
Access to photocopying facilities
Use of fax/scanning machines
Use of stationery as necessary
Use of the Trust's internal and external postal system
Use of the Trust's IT intranet and internet system

Where a trade union rep is undertaking a number of TU duties as listed in 12.2 discussions can be had between the employer and union to arrange for block facility time to undertake these duties. This could form short term blocks of time or a more long term block agreement.

Where a trade union rep holds a lead position in a trade union locally at branch, regionally or nationally, discussions can be had between the employer and union to arrange for block facility time to undertake these trade union activities.

Where agreed, the Trust will operate a ‘Deduction of Contributions at Source' (DOCAS) system at the written request of individual staff and pay such deductions to the respective trade unions. The amounts deducted will be in accordance with the rates determined by the trade unions and notified to the Trust in writing. Any changes to the subscription rates will be implemented in accordance with the Trade Union Reform and Employment Rights Act 1993.
Grievances and discipline

The Trust recognises the Trade Unions' right to represent the interests of all or any of their members at all stages during grievance and disciplinary procedures and to call in Union representatives who are not staff of the Trust wherever this is considered appropriate.

Trade Union representatives will be permitted to spend reasonable paid time inside working hours to discuss grievance and/ or disciplinary matters with affected employees, and to prepare their case, in accordance with the policy above.
Variations
This Agreement will be reviewed every 12 months. In the event of any amendments required before the review time, the Agreement may be amended at any time with the consent of both parties.
Termination of agreement

This Agreement may be terminated by providing 6 months' notice by the Trust or by the majority of recognised Trade Unions. The notice period of 6 months will be used to re-negotiate a revised Trade Union Agreement.
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available from the Employee Relations Team.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Approval and implementation
This document has been approved by the Joint Negotiating Committee (JNC) and HR Policy Working Group. The document will be available on the Trust Intranet.
Staff will be informed when documents are published and updated via the HR Policy Working Group and Trust core brief.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust aims to design and implement services, policies and procedures that meet the needs of our service, population and workforce, ensuring that none are placed at a disadvantage over others.
In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was found to be compliant with this assessment.

Appendix 2: Constitution - Joint Local NegotiatingCommittee

The Committee shall comprise of Management and representatives of the Local Negotiating Committees (LNCs) of Basildon, Broomfield and Southend Hospitals and shall be called the Joint Local Negotiating Committee (JLNC).

1.1. The three Local Negotiating Committees (LNCs) shall comprise of representatives of all grades of Medical and Dental Staff from across all sites of the Trust and shall include the BMA Full Time Officer. The Medical and Dental members of the LNC shall be members of the BMA/BDA and be accredited in line with BMA policy.
1.2. The representatives on the LNCs shall be entitled to paid time off no less than that what is contained within the ACAS Code of Practice – Time off for Trade Union Duties and Activities.
1.3. The (JLNC) shall negotiate and consult upon matters that are exclusive to medical and dental staff.

1.4. Issues of a general nature, which are applicable to all staff, will also be dealt with at the Joint Staffside Committee (JSC). The JSC shall include at least one representative of the Medical and Dental Staff from one of the three LNCs and will also allow for the BMA Full Time Officer to attend with prior notification with the JSC Chair.

2.1. The role of the JLNC shall be to negotiate, consult, discuss and agree all matters affecting medical and dental staff in the Trust pertaining to terms and conditions of service, working arrangements, policies and procedures relevant to medical and dental staff in the Trust, including arrangements for the application of national terms and conditions of service. Please note that the above are only examples and not intended to be an exhaustive list.
2.2. The JLNC are invited and shall provide a representative to attend the Trust's Joint Staffside Committee (JSC), who will provide an update to the JLNC on wider staff Trust relevant matters.
2.3. The JLNC shall be the only body recognised by the Trust for the purposes detailed above on behalf of medical and dental staff of the Trust.

3.1. To provide a framework and formality to bring together representatives of medical and dental staff to negotiate, consult, discuss, review and monitor issues of relevance and concern to Medical and Dental Staff including:

4.1.1 Any matters, general or particular affecting the employment and working arrangements of Medical and Dental Staff: for this purpose the definition of medical staff is ‘all Medical and Dental Practitioners working at the Trust' including part – time or fixed term appointments, locum and bank staff.
4.1.2 Questions of interpretation about the detailed application of Terms and Conditions of Employment for Medical and Dental Staff.
4.1.3 Local rules, policies and procedures specific to Medical and Dental Staff.
4.1.4 Issues affecting the employment of Doctors in Training, having regard to the Trust's obligation to employ Doctors in Training in accordance with the National Terms and Conditions of Employment.
4.1.5 The promotion of good employment relations and improvement in the quality of the working life for Medical and Dental Staff.

4.1.6 Terms and conditions of service relating to Medical and Dental staff employed by the Trust. Doctors' and Dentists' salaries are subject to the recommendations of the Doctors and Dentists Review Body and will therefore not form part of these negotiations.

4.1.7 The JLNC for Medical and Dental Staff shall not deal with individual grievances, disciplinary or other individual matters which are subject to the Trust's agreed procedures unless they have a bearing on collective issues.

4.1.8 To regularly monitor and review terms and conditions of service, working arrangements, policies and procedures relevant to medical and dental staff in the Trust, including arrangements for the application of national terms and conditions of service.
4.1.9 Receive and discuss with the Trust information necessary for it to undertake its role.
It is not intended for the above to be an exhaustive list.
4.1. Management recognises the Local Negotiating Committees (LNCs) of Basildon, Broomfield and Southend Hospitals who will consist of representatives of all grades of medical and dental staff.
4.2. It will be the responsibility of the three LNCs to agree their individual Constitutions and the way in which the business is conducted. This includes the election / nomination process.
4.3. The Committee shall be accountable to the Medical and Dental Staff of the Trust.

4.4. It will be the responsibility of Management to make available facilities and paid time off required for the LNCs to meet, both individually and collectively, prior to the JLNC meetings and to conduct the due processes of negotiation, consultation and discussion on behalf of the medical and dental staff of the Trust. The facilities and paid time off will be no less than what is contained within the ACAS Code of Practice on time off for Trade Union Duties and Activities.
4.5. The role of the Committee shall be to agree and represent the collective interests of medical and dental staff employed by the Trust or otherwise working in or for the Trust
MEMBERSHIP OF THE JLNC
Membership of the Joint Committee shall be as follows: -

Medical and dental staff representatives of each of the Local Negotiating Committees of Basildon, Broomfield and Southend Hospitals as nominated by these Local Negotiating Committees. It shall include a minimum of two representatives from each of the three LNCs who may be Consultants, SAS doctors or Junior doctors. It shall be for the LNCs to decide the representatives on the JLNC from their group. The nominated member shall make every effort to attend LNC/JLNC meetings and will receive paid time off and facilities.

Representatives of the Senior Management of the Group shall include the Chief Medical Officer, Chief People and Organisational Development Director, three Site  Medical Directors. They will ensure that they send a deputy on their behalf in the event they are unable to attend a JLNC meeting. The deputy shall have delegated responsibility for making decisions on behalf of the Trust at the meeting.
In addition the Head of Medical Workforce, Group Director of Medical Education and Guardian of Safe Working will be invited to attend the meeting.

Others may be co-opted as and when required to provide specialist help and advice with the prior agreement of the Chair and Deputy Chair of the JLNC. Such agreement shall not be unreasonably withheld by either group.

The facility to allow for observers to attend JLNC meetings shall not be unreasonably withheld by either group particularly for shadowing or training purposes or prior to a member of the JLNC stepping down and/or completing their term of office.

The JLNC may by prior arrangement with the Chair and the Deputy Chair of the JLNC, invite any other relevant person to attend a meeting of the JLNC. Any such invitee will not be eligible to vote nor counted in a quorum.
OFFICERS
The LNCs will appoint a JLNC Chair and Deputy Chair annually. The Chair and Deputy Chair shall be from the LNCs.
The JLNC will appoint a secretary from Management side. The agenda will be agreed in advance of sending them out at the earliest opportunity and as a minimum at least ten days prior to the meeting.

The management side secretary will be responsible for the coordinating the agenda, minutes and all administrative arrangements of the JLNC. Draft minutes will be prepared by the secretary and sent to the Chairperson for approval.
WORKING ARRANGEMENTS

Meetings will be held every 3 months (four occasions per year) or at more frequent intervals if this is desired by either Management or LNC representatives. The dates will normally be issued for the year on an annual basis for the first week of December of each given year. It shall be the responsibility of the Chair and Management secretary to do this.
A special/extraordinary meeting of the JLNC may only be called at the written request of three members.

Supporting documents in relation to agenda items will be sent electronically where possible. All notices of meetings and documents shall be sent by the Management secretary at the earliest opportunity and as a minimum at least ten days prior to the JLNC meeting taking place.
The Management Side and LNCs recognise the need to negotiate and consult in a meaningful way. Policies, procedures or agreements will be negotiated and agreed prior to implementation.
DECISIONS
JLNC members of the Committee shall be entitled to vote on any issue.
Decisions of the JLNC will be reached by a majority vote of those present.
The Committee shall decide all matters through agreement between the sides, each side coming to its own position in its own manner.
Where this is not possible, failure to agree will be recorded.
QUORUM
For a meeting to be quorate, there must be a minimum of 3 out of 6 elected members of the LNCs (two of whom must be Consultants) and 3 of the 4 Trust Management Representatives.
INTERPRETATION, VARIATION AND TERMINATION The Constitution will be subject to annual review.
There shall be no variation to this Constitution, except by joint agreement.
